Title: An algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$ has no automorphism of odd prime order
Content: Let $k=\overline k$ be an algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$ , and let $p$ be an odd prime. I want to show that there is no nontrivial automorphism $\sigma:k\to k$ with $\sigma^p=\mathrm{id}_k$ . (This is a problem from a past exam.) The provided hint suggests to show that if such a $\sigma$ exists, then a primitive $p$ th root of unity lies in the fixed field $L\subset k$ of $\sigma$ , and then to somehow use norms. I can show this first part: if $\zeta$ is a primitive $p$ th root of $1$ , then $\sigma(\zeta)^p = \sigma(\zeta^p) = 1$ so $\sigma(\zeta)$ is another primitive $p$ th root of $1$ ; hence $\sigma$ restricts to an automorphism of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)$ , i.e., an element of $G:=\mathrm{Gal}(\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)/\mathbb{Q})$ . But $G$ has order $p-1$ , so $\sigma^p = \sigma$ as elements of $G$ . Since $\sigma^p=\mathrm{id}$ , this means $\sigma$ is itself trivial on $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)$ , so $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)\subset L$ . But at this point I don't really see how to use norms to derive a contradiction. As I understand things, norms only make sense for finite extensions, but the only finite extension in sight is $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)$ , and I don't really see any contradiction to be found there. Meanwhile arbitrary elements of $L$ may not even be algebraic over $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)$ . The only other possible idea I had is to consider the finite Galois extension $F(\zeta)/F$ for $F=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$ for $\alpha\in k$ , but again I don't see what there is to say about this using norms. Any further hints or suggestions would be appreciated.
